div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,674] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 30, 1907. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamers leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: TEWFIK PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: HALOUAN, near CAIRO

Formerly the favourite Residence of the H.H. the late Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.-- Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and cold baths attached to most rooms. House warmed by special system of Radiators adjoinging the Golf Link and Race Course, Tennis, Billards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling, dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate charges. Medical Resident Director: ARTHUR J. M. BENTLEY. M.D.-- Town Office at Stephenson & Co., Opera Square, Cairo.
P.E Hergel, Manager

div.head: GRAND HOTEL, KHARTOUM.
div.p: The only First Class Hotel at Khartoum, prettily situatied in its extensive Palm Gardens on the Banks of teh Blue Nile, with commanding view from the terrace of the Hotel ove the Bluw and White Nile, Omdornian, and the Battlefields of Kerreb.
Entirely re-built. enlarged and refurbished in 1906; replete with all modern European comforts.
Electric Light, Stream Laundry, Lawn-Tennis, Stabling, Boating, own farm and Dairy products
Cosmopolitan Cuisine, European service.
Terms:-- From P.T. 100 to 125 per person and per day Special term for a prolonged stay

div.head: THE KHEDIVIAL AGRICUTLURAL SOCIETY'S SHOW.
div.p: Cairo. February 13th, 1907.
J & H. McLAREN ENGINEERS, LEEDS, ENGLAND,
be to inform their friends that they propose to have a large exhibit of
Steam Ploughing Engines
Cultivators, &c., &c.
They will aslo exhibit their new Patent
KASSABIEHS OR LEVELLINGS SCOOPS.

Eight of these scoops were sold in egypt last season for levellings sand or soil, and their working is "perfection." Agriculturalists and Land Companies interested in reclamation or cultivation are requested to visit our stand a the show and inspect out specialialties, which have been specially designed to meet the requirments of the Egyptian Market. Our Mr. Henry McLaren expects to arrive in Cairo about the 5th February. His address will be Shepherd's Hotel, and he will be glad to hear from anyone interested in the above classes of work.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.

Wednesday, January 30, 1907.

div.head: THE PREVENTION OF PLAGUE
div.p: In offering a prize of 10,000 francs for the best method of killing flies, the French journal "Le Matin" has indirectly given a great impetus in India to the crusade against palgue. The prize awarded by "Le Matin"

was gained by the advocate of "L'Huile de Schiste" a by-product from shale. A cutting form the paper was sent by Mr. R.D. Tate to Mr. Fraser, on of the staff of the "Times of India," whence it reached Dr. Turner, the exectuie health officer of Bombay. Recent eleborate experimental research as embodied in the report of the Plague Commission in India had insiputably proved that the flea was the cheif, if not the only, means of transferring the germs of plague from rats to man and from rat to rat.

Immediately this was clearly recognised, the natural corollary was to find means of getting rid of either of the rats or the fleas, or both. Whils the crusade against rats was pressed with renewed vigour, the investigations were carried out as to the most effective means of destroying fleas. It was easily show that corrosive sublimate and the usual disinfectants employed by the Indian sanitary services had little effect on fleas except, if anything, to make them more lively. On the first experiments that all that was claimed by the French investigator for l'huile de schiste as a destroyed of flies was equally true when the substance was applied to fleas. On the plague germs in artificial cultivation in the laboratory it was shown to have little effect. But on actually spreading the material on the floors and walls of plague-inflected rooms, it was found speedily to rid them of the fleas, the harbourers of the plague germs.

Elaborate experiments were crried out by Dr. Turner and Major Lamb, I.M.S., of the Plague Research Committee, which fully confirmed them in the former's belief that this residuary product of petroleum is not only the easiest and most efficacious agent for destroying rat-fleas but at the same time the only effective known remedy. So convincing was the evidence that with commendable promptitude the Bombay Municipality lost no time in commencing operations with it on a larger scale. Fifty tons of the crude material left after the distillation of petroleum, to which the appropriate name of "pesterine" was given, were obtained, and the disinfection of 2,500 of the worst plague-infected rooms was carried out. In a recent report of Dr. Turner, Execturive Health Officer of the Bombay Municipality, incontestible evidence was given that the use of this product from petroleum was, if not the direct solution of the question of how to deal most effectively with plague, certainly the best means of killing the carries of plague. The method of disinfecting a room is to sprinkle a little "pesterine" on the floow, the remove the furniture, and with a long brush, spread "pesterine" over the ceiling, then swab the walls, and finally with a broom brush the thick fluid all over the floors. The substance is not readily inflammable, and its use does not damage the interior of houses.

Although at present the substance, practically hiterto a waste product, is infinely cheaper than other disinfectats-- almost absurdly so, as for a few pence a whole house can be disinfected-- it is probale that the demand in the future will enhance its value. Thus it has been noticed that the spreading of this materaial on earthen floors makes a surface in many was similar to asphaltem and already is suggested to use it as a possible solution to the great dust problem aggravated by the introduction of motors.

Fortunately plague now-a-days never makes much headway in Egpyt, although the means of combating it entrails considerable cost to the sanitary services. Its recurrence from time to time, however, more especially in the three chief ports, necessitating some inconvience to and a heavy tax on, commerce, suggests, that the wholesale treatment block by block, of at least all cellar bordering on our wharves, as well as all houses known to have been infected at any time during the present decade, on the lines carried out in Bombay, might perhaps be the most effectual barrier of quarentine that could be imposed. All other precautionsand regulaitons seem long ago to have forfeited the confidence of the public, who are seldom scrupulous in evading suhc restrictions. A wholesale crusade against rats and fleas would show that our authorites were alive to the importance of checking, and if possible, exterminating the evil. It would be too much to expect cooperation from the people, either European or native, as people are notoriously apathetic on all such subjects unless they are aroused by an immediate danger to their own existence or wellbeing.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterdays' plague bulletin records a fatal case at Ismailia, a case at Mellawi, and a recovery at Alexandria.

div.head: Earmarked.
div.p: IN the course of a quarrel yesterday between two natives in the service of the Alexandria Tramway Company, one bit the other's ear off.

div.head: The Brindlel.
div.p: The mail from Europe, Via Brindisi and Port Said, will arrive at Alexandria this afternoon and will be distributed at the G.P.O at 9 p.m.

div.head: Execution.
div.p: Ahmed Matta, a native of Menonufish, who murded another native of Menshat Shenwan on the 15th September lst, was executed on Monday morning in Tantah Prison.

div.head: British Club.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the members of the British Club, LAexandria, will be held at the club on Saturday next at 9 p.m. Busines: to pass accounts for the 1906. To elect a general committee for 1907. To comfirm rules subject to modifications.

div.head: The Weather.
div.p: Terrible weather was met with in the Mediterranean by the North German Llyod S.S. Schleswig, which arrived here consideribly overdue yesterday afternoon. Between Marseilles and Naples the sea was so bad that the Schleswig was a day late in arriving at the Italian port. She has 203 passengers on baord, and is leaving this afternoon at 3 o'clock with 94 passengers.

div.head: Warning to Visitors.
div.p: Our many visitors, who on their way homewards from Egypt go through Italy, should be more careful than every of their baggage for thefts on the railways are becoming very common. On the 19th inst. the Hon. Duffe Tollemach and Mrs. Tollemacha, who left Rome by the morning express for Florence, quitted the train for lunch at Chinsi. On their return to the thei carriage they found that a portmanteau had been opened and valuable to the amount of 200 had been stolen.

div.head: Burning a Bowab.
div.p: The police authorities at Alexandria have closed the enquiry in the case of Mr. Alexander Masoha, the Greek who is accused of having set fire to his bowab while asleep. The Greek's defence is that be is so short-sighted he is almost blind. He lives in the building where the bowab is employed. About twenty days ago the bowab and a number of his friends were making a great noise and the man called down from his house and told the bowab to keep quiet. If not he threatened that he would burn him. He never intended to carry out his threat. Lately, on account of the cold weather the bowab made a fire and owing to sitting too close to it his garments caught alight and he was burnt to death. The accusation that the Greek was a party to the bowab's death is now said only to rest on the idle threat which he did not mean to execute, and it was by a pure coincidence that the man happened to be burnt to death some days afterwards owing to his own fault. The bowab, who disliked the Greek, before be died declared that his death was due to the latter. The bowab's sister, bowever, now contradicts her brother's dying statement. An enquiry is still contiouing at the Hellenic Consolate.

div.head: Lectures at Y.W.C
div.p: A very original form of entertainment for Cairo was that given at the Y. W. C. A. rooms at Connaught House on Tuesday afternoon, when the representative of the H. J Heinz Company gave a practical demonstration of the many and varied products of this enterprising company. The lady lecturer, Miss McLeod, has already paid extensive visits to many countries, spreading the name and reputation of her employers in foreign lands. Her travels have led her to India, the Straits Settlement", Siam, the Philippine Islands, S. Africa, Australia and other places, where she has met with most kind reception and en-couragment. While in Siam she had the honour of preparing and serving a dinner to the King ; and sixty of his suite ; and while in Australia her demonstrations and popular lectures were attended by many of the wives of the high officials. The entertainment on Tuesday partook more of the nature of a friendly "At I Home" than a leature, and a varied menu, consisting of stuffed olives, a very special brand of tomato soup, baked beans, mince meat, apple butter crackers. cherry ice, and other dainties were offered to the guests who filled the room. Silver chafing dishes steaming on the table were need in the preparation of these delicacies ; and Miss McLeod was kept hard at work explaining the manufacture of these valuable foodstuffs and the manner in which to serve them to best advantage. An interesting little pamphlet entitled "The Spice of Life" was also handed around to the assembled guests, the perusal of which will certainly convince most that of will the modern necessites in the store cupboard, whether at home or abroad, there are none more valuable than those supplied by Messrs. H. J Heinz & Co.

div.p: London, Wednesday
Sir J. Swettenham has withdrawn his letter to Admiral Davis and apologised for the same.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: As already announced by us, H.H. the Khedive started yesterday on his trip in the Western desert. When the Khedivial train arrived at Kilometre 35, near Mahatta Hawarie, a change of locomotives rendered necessary and another one was brought from Wardian station. At Bahig his highness recieved Mr. F.C. Ewald Falls, on of the german archeaologists at work in old Menas city, who gave a brieg account of the excavations.

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: The Khedive will deliver a speech at the meeting of the General Assembly in Cairo on the 28th prox. in presence of the Ministers. His Highness will deal with the reforms which have been introduced by the Government since the last meeting of the Assembly.

div.head: EXPRESS NILE STEAMERS
div.p: The S.S. Virginia, the latest addition to the fleet of the Express Nile Steamers Co., made her maiden voyage from Luxor to Assouan on Sunday, in connexion with the daily service established between those two stations. Against the stream she ran nine knots, mean speed. The Virginia is admirably adapted to tourist traffic, and her luxurious fittings are the subject of pop larencemim. The S.S. America, of the same line, which left Cairo for Luxor the same day, had on board the following passengers: - Mr. G. Loring. Miss F. Pidgeon, Mr Frederick E. Smith, Mrs Smith, Mrs. L C Ware, Mrs. K B Knowles Rev. H.A. Man- chester. Mrs. Manchester Mr W.B Smith Mrs. Smith. Mr K A Tinhorn, Mr. M. C Calloch, Pétrir, Mr S.S. div.head: ART IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr, A. O. Lemplough, A M. S. K , who during the last lew years has made so great name for himself as a painter of Egyptian landscapes, has returned from Luxor and reopened his exhibition at the National Hotel. The water colours which he has brought back with him from Upper Egypt excel any which he has hitherto exhibited, and we are convinced that it is no exaggeration to assert that for delicacy and richness of colouring, with which is combined an unnsual accuracy in the drawing, the best of his latest efforts are unsurpassable. The succes of his exhibition amply proves tbe appreciation of his former clinets, and at the same time his clinetele is increasing daily. Yesterday after-noon, among the distinguished visitors who inspected Mr. Lamploogh's exhibition, were Prince Mohamed Aly and Prince Ibrahim Halim. Both expressed their admiration of Mr. Lamploogh's skill in the faithful portrayal of Egyptinn landscapes, and Prince Mohamed Aly has purchased perhaps the best of his latest paintings, a beautiful evening river scene at Luxor, in which tha various colours of this country's enchanting afterglow are reproduced with most perfect truthfulness. Prince Ibrahim Halim bought the picture "The Pyramids from above Cairo," which we have commented opon before, in which the mist effect is brought out wonderfully.

Among others of Mr. Lamploogh's Cairo patrons bave keen Mr. Alexaxander Smyrnoff, Major Blant, Col. Garner, Capt. Stookwell, Lt. Levchine, Sir John Rogers, Lady Willcocks, Mr. M de C. Pindlay, Major General Sir John Ardagh, aud many others.

div.head: STEAMSHIP COMPANY'S ACTION.
div.p: The Alexandria agency of the Russian Steam Navigation and Commercial Company have written to their head office at Odessa to notify the facts connected with the havoc made on board the S.S. Imperator Nicholas by the mob on Saturday week. It is not as yet known what steps the company will take in the matter. When the S.S. Imperator Nicholas arrices at Odess the company will officially estimate the damage done to the steamer and then a decision will be arrived at as to what line of policy should be followed in regard to obtaining compensation

div.head: NATIVE PRESS AND THE "AFFAIR."
div.p: Our opinion of the common-sense of certein of tge leaders of the "Nationalist" party was never very high, but we are amazed to find "Al Moayad" in the same galley as Mustapha Pasha Kamel—unless our excel- lent confrere has been chained to the bench by the Editor of "Al Lewa." "Al Moayad's" article on the "Russian affair" it worthy of the ingenious tribune : there it the same extraordinary bias, the same urious illogicality. In fact, so deeply does the author deplore the fact that Lord Cromer's views on the Capitulations have been justified by events that he can hardly refrain from insunuationsi that tne Alexandria manifestations were, what is vulgarly termed, "a put-op job," e g., firstly, what of the genuine or feigned incapability of the Alexandria police to prevent the outrage on the Russian Consulate and the insult to the Imperial escutcheon when the Cairo police, were able to guard the Russian Vice Consulate from attack and in-sult." Again we read, à propos of Lord Cromer's reply to M.M. Chalom and Rossi : "Thus Lord Cromer has allowed a crying injustice to be committed to enable him to argue in favour of his personal opinions on the Capitulations."

We should like to point out that our contemporary has completely barked the real question at issue, viz., "Were the Egyptian Government and the representative in Cairo of the British Occupation justified in refus- ing to commit a violation of international law on behalf of three felons ?" Of the Russians, two coofessed their participation in a plot to blow up a steamer on which some few Egyptians would probably have been passengers. We fail to see how such an act would benefit humanity, liberty in Russia, or any cause but that of autocracy. So the less about "crying injustice" the better. Does "Al Moaysd" really wish Egypt to be the base of operations for European Anarchists. Nihilists, and others? Strange forms of patriotism have at times been professed by Egyptians, btt this is the strangest.

Again, if the police at Alexandria failed to disperse the crowd, was not that due to the numbers of the assailants and the vigour of - their tactics. At Cairo they had the warning from Alexandria. "But none are so deaf," etc. 'Al Moayad" endows Lord Cromer with designs for the extinction of Egyptian liberties, and when our representative proposes modifications in the régime which has long fettered, and we fear may long fetter BEgypt, our con- temporary hints at Macchiavelli.

So much for an article wherein insinuation usurps the place of thought. What our Nationalists have always lacked is constructive criticism. We have heard of many Egyptian Parliaments, but never of the details of their organisation. We have heard numerous critiques of the educational system but never seen an alternative scheme proposed by Egyptians. And now our good contemporary is very angry at the 'crying injustice" that has been com- mitted. but cannot give the Government any reasonable advioe as to how react next time three individuals try to make Egypt their base of operations against a friendly Power.

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: "RIGOLETTO."

"Rigoletto"—that "somewhat faded music," as a London critic once called it—was duller than ever last night. The compaoy seemed to lose all interest in it—small blame to them. Signor Battani did let himself go to some extent in "La donna e mobile," and of course was encored. His voice is, if anything, more charming than ever. Signor Vecchioni's "make-up" was rather weird: so far as I could see in the dim light that surrounds Spara- fucile, be had a red wig and an inked blaok beard that looked rather like a section of a mask fastened on to his chin. No one sang badly,but every one seemed bored. "Rigoletto" should be given piecemeal, and not all at once. It is too long and dreary, and the few songs of note in it are all so much alike—for that matter they are just like some of Verdi's other songs. Compare "La donna" to "Di Quells Pira," for instance, or even to "A che l'amore," and you will find almost the same time and accompaniment in all three. And then "Rigoletto" has not the fresh vigour that saves Verdi's worst work as a rule, and makes his best work brilliant.

div.head: CRICKEY.
div.p: EGYPT v. M.C.C. (GENTLEMEN)
A match has been arranged between Egypt and the Gentlemen of the M.C.C to take Place at Lord's on June 19.

div.head: SALT & SODA.
div.p: THE AMALGAMATION RUMOUR.

The rumour current concering the amalgamation of the Salt and Soda Company with the Port Said Salt Association is unfounded. All that has happened is simply the conclusion of an "entente" betwwen the two companies in regard to the sale of salt, so as to do away with the competition which is doing harm to both companies.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS
div.p: there has been some strong buying of the shares of this company of late, due ot the fact that the balance of unissued captial, viz., 50,000 is about to be issued and will be offered to the present shareholds very shortly at 27s 6d. per share. Sharholders of every fire shares will therefore be entitled to apply for two new shares.

This issure has been decided upon in view of an important concession granted to the company by the Governmeny. This concession grants to the company the sole right of importation of nitrate manures into Egpypt, for which there is a large and increasing demand.

The Government furthe agrees to forgo all rights to participate in any profits accuring to the company from this business and also agrees not to levy any tax on nitrates so imported until 31st December 1909, after which date they will have a claim as heretofore.

div.head: DELTA LANDS
div.p: After consideration, the Government, we understand, have decided to abandon the idea of locating the new sewage farm required for the disposal of the Cairo sewage on the Government desert land between Meadi and Tonrah, near the property of the Delta Land Co. Several alternative schemes are under consideration, and it is expected that a decision will be arrived at during next month.

We underatand that the recent differences between the looal and London boards have been amicably settled. The number of the London board will now be reduced to three and the Cairo board increased to four, thus giving the local board the balance of power. Mr. Rafael Suares will be one of the new local directors.

div.head: BIG PROPERY DEAL
div.p: The magnificent estate in Rosetta Gatestreet, belonging to the Enterprises Urbaines et Rurales, on which stand the Zizina Theatrem the Austro-Hungarian Consulate, and the Galleries Lafayette, has been bought by Mr. Charles Bacos for 150,000. The estate comprises 13,730 square pics. The Enterprises Urbanies et Rurales purschased the land at about 5 per pic, which gives a profit to the company of one hundred per cent.

div.head: BRITISH ENTERPRISE IN EGYPT.
div.p: Tbe constructional iron and steel trade of this contry has for years past been almost en- tirely in the bands of Continental contractors, as apparently British firms of the low prices obtainable here, preferred pushing their work in the colonies, where better prices were obtainable. As we have constantly urged in our columns that Brirish firms should pay more attention to our local market, we are pleased to note that a British firm is now beating the Continental firms in open oompetition.

Our representative yesterday visited the workshops of the Egyptian Constructions, where a large amount of work is in course of construction, as well as of some of their completed contracts, and he was astonished at the progress which has been made in the short time which has elapsed since the flota-tion of the company. One of the structures we visited was a steel cotton shed built for the state Railways, covering the enormous area of two-abd three quarter feddans, and some rather smaller buildings are in hand for Gabbari, Zagszig, Luxor, etc.

One is surprised after a visit to such work- shops as these to realise to what a large extent Egypt is able to meet her own requirements when assisted by thoroughly efficient European supervision and direction. The Egyptian Constructions, by taking advantage of local labour and carefully training same, can carry out contracts at prices unapproachable by Continental firms, and at the same time make them very remunerative to them- selves.

div.head: GAIETY AT SHEPHEARD'S.
div.p: THE BALL COTILLON.

Those who have to do with the management of Sbepheard'a Hotel have every reason to congratulate themselves on the success of their ball cotillon of last Monday. There is not another hotel in Egypt that could have coped with suoch a situation, or could have provided the accomidation required by the crowds of guests who clamoured for invitations. It is said that over 800 people sat down to dinner that evening, and by ten o'clock there must have been close to 1,000 packed in the passages and huge dining-hall, which had been transformed into the ball-room. So great was the crunch that it became impossible to find one's friends, and any detailed account of individuals is impossible. Dancing, too, during the earlier hours of the evening was almost an impossibility, abd not even the very best of dancers could be sure of preserving their partners from untoward contretemps. But whether dancing or lookiog on, there was no lack of excitement and interest in the scene, for amid the ever-changing kaleidoscope of people fresh friends would be discovered at every turn, and never more fitting scenes for the pretty dresses could bave been devised than those afforded by the ball room with its strings of colored lights and long trails of coloured foliage, and the handsome hangings and decorstions of the adjoining ball with its softly playing fountain.

The cotillon which gave this ball its special signifigance was marked down towards the end of the programme ; but the first and most important figures commenced much earlier in the evening, and when the crowd was at its height. As last year Dr. Armstrong undertook the arduous task of leader, and with his partner headed the long list of fair women and brave men who paraded room the room. With the distribution of pretty favours, head dresses, sunflower trophies, and the like, a medley and unwonted appearance was given to the dancers as they strove to circle around the room amid the onlookers ; and as the various figures resulted in mere and more favours being dispensed, there were but few who did not carry at least one of these dainty mementoes. But numbers were too great to allow of this graceful and popular dance being carried out in its entirety during the earlier part of the evening, though the prettiest of surprises made its appearanoe before the ordinary business of the programme was resumed. The great long curtains at the end of the room were drawn apart to disclose an immense balloon radiant with eleotric light from within, which floated into the centre of the room. Flowers decorated the body of the balloon, flowers covered the basket which hung before it, and in the centre ot this mass of blooms was a diminutive little person who dispensed his favours with impartiality upon those who clamoured below him. No prettier, or more novel sight could be imagined than this little lad in his decoratad and glowing airship ; and again may the management of Shepheard's be congratulated on having happened on such a brilliant idea.

Many people spent the next few dances at super, while those whose requirements were of a simpler nature fouod everything they wanted at the superb buffet which ministered to their wants. Here were to be found all the delicacies of the season, both of a sweet and savoury nature, and a thick crowd of both hungry and thirsty pleasure seekers buzzed round the groaning tables between the dances for the remainder of the evening. As numbers grew fewer in the ball-room her cotillon figures were introduced, perhaps the most entertaining one being that in which the gentlemen had to make their way in sacks from one end of the room to where the ladies of their choice sat at the other, the ladies wearing round their necks large velvet hearts with suitable motroes inscribed thereon.

The delightful music supplied by the sextett orchestra kept things going till after three o'clock; and when the last tired but still cheer- ful parties left the room tha curtain was rung down at what must be remembered as one of the very best balls ever known in Cairo.

As before mentioned the list of dinners served in the hotel that night numbered some eight hundred, and no accurate list can be given of those which must have taxed the cuisine to it utmost. But among the parties mention must be made of that given by Major and Mrs E. S. Herbert, whose guests included Capt. and Mrs. Hunter, Mrs. Stanley Bird, Miss Gorst, Lord Edward Cecil, and Mr. Carter Wilson; and that given by Messers. Rom and Curphy. Mr. aud Mrs. George Nongovich Bey had a party of fourteen. Mrs. Saunders entertained an even larger number, and among other hosts and hostesses were Mr. Ferdinande Martino Bey, H H. Prince Ibrahim Hassan, Mr. and Mrs. Sahreiber, Major Tucker, Prince de Brancovan, Baron and Baroness de Buggenhager, Professor S. H. Osborne, Mr. von Marovski, Mr. Cunoliffs Owen, Bimbasbi Porter, Lieut. Holland, Col. Jones, Baron and Baroness von McLunhof, Baroness von Kunov, Omar Bey Cherif, and Lieut. von Beyersdorf.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord and Lady Vivian are staying at the Savoy. Lord vivian is fourth baron and succeeded his father in 1893. The first Baron Vivian, who was highly distinguished contry officer, led the charges at Waterloo, and became equerry to George IV, adn the third baron was Ambassador at Brussels and Rome. Lord Vivian is a late Lieutenant of the 17th Lancers and served in the South African war, in which he was severely wounded.

Sir Nowell Salmon, who is at Mena House with Lady Salmon, is one of our most distinguished naval officers. He entered the Royal Navy in 1847 and passing through the various grades became Admiral of the fleet in 1839.

"Many happy returns of the day" to Sir William Garstin. K C.M G whose birthday was yesterday. Sir William is the son of the late Charles Garstin, of the Bengal Civil Service, and was born in India. He was educated at Cheltenham College, and in October 1872 he was appointed to the Indian Public Works Department. He left India for Egypt in 1895 and was appointed Inspector General of Irrigation in May 1892 and in the following year Under Sectetary of State for Public Works. In 1899 he made trips down the White and Blue Niles, his journey ending respecitevly 200 and 700 miles south of Khartoum, and in 1904 he made a journey of 7,0OO miles for the purpose of investigating the sources of the Nile. In 1904 he was made Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works.
Lady Huntington accompanied by her eldest son, Sir Leslie Huntington, and other memebers of the family, arrived in Cairo yesterday.
Mustapha Pasha Ibady. Governor of Alexandria is still confined to bed with a bad attack of influenze. Mme Ibadi Pasha will not be "at home" until his Excellency has quite recovered.
Mrs. Gedge's children's fancy dress party has been postponed until the 6th inst.

Mr. Lloyd George speaking at Walsall, said that the Government would greatly assist trade as Germany was doing. He has arranged for the Foregin Office to have important trade information telegraphed to the Board of Trade for transmission to the Chambers of Commerce. All Consuls must in future pass through the Intelligence Department of the Board of Trade. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SWETTENHAM INCIDENT.
INTERNATIONAL PHASE CLOSED

div.p: Sir J. Swettenham has withdrawn his letter to Admiral Davis and expressed his regret at the misunderstanding, thus finally closing the international phase of the incident. (Reuter)
Friendly messages have been exchanged between the Tsar and Emperor of China, and also between St. Petersburg and Tokyo, with regards to the evacuation of Manchuria.

The German Embassy has sent a note to the Porte demanding imperatively the punishment of the Sultan's protege Fehim Pasha, cheif of the secret police at Yildz, on account of the seizure of a German cargo of timber. (Reuter)

300 natives have risen in revol at Kediri (Java). They killed the native chief of the polic and severely wounded the vice-governor of the province and another Dutch official, and killed or wounded many others. (Reuter)
There are 72 cases of cereberal meningitis here, of which 12 have already turned fatal. (H.)

The declariation drawn up by the French Bishops, approved by the Pope, which has been published, displayed a general disposition to accept the benefits of the Law of 1907, provided that certain perogatives of the Church are upheld. (Reuter)

The officals now announce that only 161 men were below in the St. Johann mines at the time of the explosion. 77 bodies have been recovered. The fate of the rest is hopless, as the fire is still raging. (Reuter)
The Emperor has thanked M.Fallieres for his condolences in the name of the German people. (Havas)
The Emperor has sent Prince Frederick Leopold to Roden on account the victims of the firedamp explosion (Havas)
The Upper House has passed all the bills voted by the deputies. (Havas)

Results of the elections continues to arrive from various centres and are strongly commented upon. The enormus success of teh NAtionalist part in Munich is a manifestation in favour of the Empire as well as of the total defeat of the Guelpha in the Duchy of Brunswick. It is estimated that the Socialist Part will lose all together in the elections about 30 seats. (Havas)

There is a growing realisation here that the Centre has emerged first in the ballots and is stronger than ever. The Clerical organ "Germania" says that Herr Dernburg is doomed to bitter disappointment if he imagines that the Centre will hasten to the assistance of teh Government in its colonial projects. (Reuter)

div.head: TO THE EDITOR TO THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Dear Sir,—Allow me to say a few words about your leading article of yesterday, 'The German Elections." According to my opinion— and I think this opinion-- will be shared by all of your readers who have any sense of logic-- the conclusionss arrived at in this article and the interpretation it gives to the result of the German elections, are simply absurd. Let me prove it by briefly tracing the history of these elections, which may perhaps be unknown to many of your readers.

In December last the Reichstag refused, by a small majority, the credits which the Government had asked for the continuation of the war in South Africa. Now the Government had every reason to believe that this vote was not in accordance with the views of the majority of the nation and that this Reichstag, which had been elected four years ago, was not the true representative of German opinion any more. The Reichstag was there- fore dissolved, and the German electors were asked to say their word in the matter. This they have done now, and as far as we can see, and if the second ballots do not change the aspect of things, the nation has decided in favour of the continuation of the war and for the maintenance of the colony, as was to be expected.

Now suppose the same thing had happened in England. Suppose the Boer war was to break out again, and a majoirty of "Little Englanders" in Parliament refused the necessary credits to the Government. Then Parliament would be dissolved and an appeal made to the electors who would certainly return a majority in favour of the war. Now would you, in this aase. publish a leading article saying that the British nation had deaided to be governed directly by King Edward and his representatives, in preference to exercising themselves a controlling influence over their destiny in That the British people had replied to King Edward's challenge with all due submissiveness and had deliberve by thrown away their rights. Certainly not or if you did, everybody would think it nonsense. Way, then, say such things in our case, which is absolutely identical, and describe as a decision in favour of a it in favor to autocratic what was simply the vote of the nation in a single political question.

Some time ago you depleted it in your very paper that the German press, when writing about Great Britain, was often showing much misapprehension and ignorance of the real facts. Allow me to say that, to judge by yesterday's article. this apparently not united to German journalists alone, but that their British colleagues. to seem often to blame for the same imperfectors when writing about German matters.—1 am, etc.
H.L. Alexandria, 29th Jaunary.

div.head: THE ENGLISH IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Dear Sir, --Will you kindly allow me to make a few remarks upon a letter signed "G.J.S," Cairo, 9th January published in your paper. It is evident that "G. J. S." has not studied the question why the English are not liked by the Egyptians in spite of the benefits of English rule, for, to attribute this want of feeling to the unsociability of the English individual is childish. In my opinion it is going too far to say that the English are hated by the people over whom they rule. The most that one may say is that they are not liked, and that is, I think, very natural. His tory, which is worth more than any newspaper arguments, teaches us that no people with any claim to racial distinction has ever put up with foreign rule, however just and light that rule was. And to expeot from any such people to love the race that has by some means or other subjugated them, is ridioulous.

"G. J. S." says that he himself loves and esteems the Engliah because he, as an exceptional, has had some opportunities of assooiating with the English. Surely, unless "G. J. S " is a "rare avis," there most exist in the British colonies a large number of persons who have had "G. J. S." opportunities, and yet the persons in the British colonies that prefer English rule to home rule are not many, and still less are those that love the English.

It is obvious that "G J S" has not had the execptional opportunities he claims to have had ; otherwise, he would have been in a position to attribute this "dislike to British rule" to more natural causes than the unsocialbility of the English character. I am ready to agree with "G. J. S." that English officials in the colonies (I had better say of one colony only, for unlike "G J. S." my experienoe does not extend to all British oolonies) do not associate much with the native element. But this, also, is very natural. Britishers are not cosmopolitan, although they know the world better than the people of any other country. Their daily life is ruled by certain strict rules of etiquette which differs from the etiquette of any other European races. Their habits and inclinations, their manners and tastes, generally differs. They are in this respect a people apart from the rest of the people of Europe, with the result that a Britisher finds it very difficult to be "chummy" with a foreigner. If there, the Britishers cannot make themselves at home in a French or German house, and they are not "at their ease" in the company of other Europeans, how can '"G. J. S." expect them to cultivate the society of Orientals whose habits and manners are still farther away from them than those of other Europeans. To ask ann Englishman,for instance, to make himself "at home" in an Oriental gentleman's house where are served for dinner a dozen so dishes of unknown composition and of well-known but unrelished odours, and where the ladies of the house entertain him with a narghileh and a plate of salted bonbons before them, is asking for the impossible.

No; I am afraid that G. J. S " knows very little of ths Englishman's domestic life-- likes and dislikes. We all know that Britishes were liked in Egypt before their occupation of it, and why are Britishers liked anD appreciated in such places as France, Italy and Swizerland. It is because all the admirers of the Britishers in these countries have had the exceptional opportanities of "G. J. S." ? -- Yours faithfully,
Larnaca, Cyprus, Jan. 24.

div.head: INTERESTING TO TOURISTS
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir,-- Some of your readers who are intendingg to visit Europe may be glad to hear of an unusually charming and attractive spot in the Tyrol,but as yet littleknown though very easily teached from Italy or Trieste Windisch Matrei is the chief village of this district, and is very favourably situated for excursions, being at the juncture of three valleys, all og great beauty. It is a good mountaineering centre, and have also attractions for the angler and for the antiquarin. Tne river supplies several mile, of good trout fishing, best in June and Sep- tember, and in the neighbourhood are two very ancient churches, both decorated with curious and interesting frescoes. ON the road to the churches are two most remarkable pillars with frescoes but unfortunately notnothing authentic is known of their origin.Traces of Roman occupation exist in the neighborhood, many coins having been dog up, and parts of the grand old Castle of Weissenstein, which standabout 200 feet above the village, are said to have been built by them. This interesting old castle has bean judiciously restored and fitted with every modern requirement, and now accomidates a little over 34 visitors. I- is conducted on the lines of a first class English country house, and is open from June 1st till the end of October. In the castle grounds are two well kept tennis courts. The elevation of the castle is 3,110ft. above sea level, and the air is particularly bracing and pure, Weissenstein Castle is suitable for a prolonged stay, and has the advantage of being off the usual tourist routes. The station is Lienz in the Punter Valley about one hour and a half by train from Toblacb, the well-known entrance to the Ampezzi Vallay in the region of the Dolomites. From Lientz the castle is reached in a little over three hours by private carriage, or somewhat longer by public diligence.
TRAVELLER.

div.head: UPPER EGYPT
div.p: THE LUXURIES OF TRAVEL

Though of course there is no way of traveling in Egypt to pleasant as by dababieb, there are many to whom time is an object, and who cannot indulge in this easy and deliberate method of seeing the country. The railway journey between Cairo and Assouan in the past has often been held up to contumely; but really at the present moment, when it comes to an honest analysis, the journey is by no means a tedious one : and indeed it is a remarkable achievement when one considers the difficulties under which the line has been engineered, and the natural conditions surrounding it.

For the sake of argument, let us suppose the jonrney to Assouan has been undertaken by dshabieb, and then let us take the return trip from Assouan Cairo by the mail train, which leaves the former place every day during the winter season at 10.15 a.m. Those who remember the dusty, inconvenient little station of Assouan planed across the road by the landing stage will not recognize the trim garden with its spin-and-span little buildings of red brick and turquoise cloured woodwork now enclosed by a neat walk and fencing. No longer a rabble crowd gathers before the booking office: for separate entraces divide the different classes, and no one is allowed to enter on the platform without a ticket, even though the ticket is issued for that purpose alone. Fresh arrangements are also made in the matter of luggage, which no longer cumbers the platform, but which is taken straight to its own department to be weighed and registered and placed upon the train without confusion. In the same way the arriving luggage is removed from the vans at the further end of the platform and carried away through another exit without ever encroaching on the platforms. A neat telegraph office stands in line with the booking office and that of the International Wagons Lits Company, and on the other side of it if a comfortable and airy waiting-room prettily furnished with basket chairs, the lavatory accommodation being also in a separate building well kept and filled with all necessaries, clean towels and soap being among its luxuries. The train, which still runs on the narrow gauge (3ft 6 in.) single line is composed of first-class coaches and restaurant cars painted white in addition to the ordinary rolling stock. These long white coaches are divided each into two compartments with tiled lavatory accommodation in the centre. The compartments are not furnished as in ordinary trains, but have a sofa seat each side on ball their length, the remaining space being occupied by easy chairs with leather cushions and tables. The windows are protected as far as possible from the sand and sun by glass windows, both colourless and blue, as well as the ordinary

shutters. An ice chest is also added to each compartment, so that passengers can carry a few necessary and grateful drinks with them if they wish to do so, and for the extra-luxurious there are spocial carriages which can be attached to the train at special rates. The restaurant cars are as comfortable as they can be, and are furnished with electric fans. Here lunches are served either a la carte or from the menu and there is a separate small saloon for those who wish for extra meals, for teas, or such like, at odd times.

So much for Assouan station and the train as they stand at the moment. They argue well for those who here had to do with them during the last few months, and compare most favourably with the conditions existing even last winter. There are rumours in the air of still greater improvements to be made in the future; of the possibility of the wider gauge and double line, with the continuation of a more elaborate service but these things still lie in the laps of the gods, and a certain number of years are bound to elapse before their consummation.

Jonrneying Itz'y by dahabieh one sees of course the native life of the river banks, but little of that which lies beyond. From the elevation of that train one learns far more of the country around, and as it winds its way across the desert, through mud villages, and skirting the fields of crops, the groves of palms, etc., etc., the hours slip by with many of j cts of interest to pass the time away. Right throngh the heart of Assouan runs the line, a crowd of women and children turning out to spell the parting train as it borrows in and out through the close built walls, through rough cuttings and out past the mud encampments and cemetery beyond. For many miles the rails form the dividing line between the cultivated ground upon ths river side and the stony stony of the desolate hill sides, and its track serves in the absence of the train as the chief thoroughfare for beast and waylarer.

Through Khattore, now curving by the river bank, now far away across the desert with the mountains fading away into the distance. stopping for a few minutes at Daraw, a quite important native town, with a crowd of women and children at the station selling brightly coloured woven bags and flags, and so on to Kom-Ombo with the beautiful temple hidden by the hill behind it and the hideous water works, blazoning the commercial prosperity of its future. The native town is a large one; European houses are springing up round the station and the large area of land enclosed by deep dykes is that pet sc heme in which Sir Ernest Cassel is so much interested. Silwa and Serag are passed duringg the hour for lunch, an excellent meal and excellently served, end from the station of Edfon there is no glimpse of the temple which lies across the further side of the river. At Mahamid one notices the frequent pigeon towers and also some attempt to beautify the mud village houses with triangular pointed cornices of coloured

bricks. The station of Esneb lies some 1 1/2 mile from the river and away from the town, which shows faintly on its opposite bank. The tract between the station and the river is given over to the machinations of Sir John Aird and Co. and is covered with huge piles of stone, and all the desolation of desolation which must perforce accompany the stupendous work which is being there erected. The hill side between Matana andChagab are now being quarried for the same purpose, busy swarms of workers hanging like flies upon its surface.

The heat of the day has passed its zenith before one gets to Armant, after which one can let down the window and enjoy the glorious view over the window and verdant plain with no thought of dust interfering with one's plea sure ; and before the sun has gone to rest the trusty train has landed one in Luxor station, if somewhat dusty and thirsty still but little tired after the seven hours journey.

Here at Luxor the traveler has a grateful change and rest till 6.30, when the night mail bears him away to Cairo. So there is time to test the resources of the station, shake the dust from one's clothes, enjoy an ample ablution in a commodious dressing-room, and thoroughly appreciate a welcome thirst quencher, either tea or otherwise, on the verandah which is attached to the station buffet, and which is in the hands of the Wagons Lits Company.

By six o'clock the long mail train is in the Station, so there still remains half an hour to find one's compartment and leisurely bestow one's belongings to best advantage luck is in the ascendant one gets a compartment all to oneself, and can study one's own comfort all the time, open windows and ventilators at one own sweet will, set miniature electric fans a-working, and admire one's own appearance without let or hindrance at no less than three looking glasses of goodly proportions. The seats are wide and delightfully cushioned, the dressing room quite replete, with a basin commodious enough to satisfy the most particular. While in the restaurant can discussing dinner, the attendants have been busy setting out the beds, so that on one's return to the compartment one is almost tempted there and then to disrobe and test their quality. One's ticket has also been removed from one's custody, so that there is no fear of having the night made hideous by frequent visits by the collectors all eager to show their devotion to their duty.

So the black hours of the night slip by and unless one is a very delicate sleeper one manages to get a really comfortable rest, for the motion is by no means rough, and there are not many stations to break the continuity of slumber. In the chilly hours of early morn the train was through Kafr Ammah; the sun is well up and flooding the country round Matarieh, breakfast makes a welcome break soon after, and then the familiar features of Cairo surroundings heave in sight, Pyramids of Darsbieh, and of Sakara, on one side ; Helooan sparkling on the side. Then the Pyramids of Ghizereh come nearer, the train crosses the shady road that leads thereto, and the long detour beyond is made which leads to the big bridge below Ghezireh across to Bonlao, and so back to the big terminus at Cairo well up to time, and quite ready to start the busy day with the rest of the world at large.

div.head: AN AMERICAN AT THE COURT OF MENELIK
div.p: Tbe average B-ilon knows, probably, little shout Abyssinia. Mr. Skinner, the first representative of the United States to visit the Court of the King of Kings, evidently believes that his fellow citizens know nothing of the country. In this belief he has written a book based on the experience—November, 1903- January, 1904—when head of a mission rent to negotiate a treaty of commenrce between the U.S.A. and Menelik II Mr. Skinner went, saw, and was conquered. He imagined himself, and with some reason, an ingestigation of "a civilization which found its inspiration in Solomon's Court." and with refreshing enthusiasm be records his first impressions of the East, for it is to the East rather than to Africa that Abyssinia, save geographically, belongs. For the Negros he displays a whole-hearted admiration, crediting him with "the constructive intelligence of a Bismarck, and the faculty for handling men by sheer amiability of a McKinley" Mr. Skinner's descriptions of the ex- periences of the mission alike capital reading his comments on trade and commerce are much to the point.

Concerning the Abyssinians themselves, their history, their religion, their laws, and such-like matters, the information given is somewhat crude and elementary, nor altogether free from error-e.g. the irritating references to Christopher de Gama. But the point if view taken is always novel and usually round. Perhaps the real defect of the bank lies in the fact that the author saw only the very best side of the Abyssinians, and writer as if the whole nation was equal to the samples tested. We heartily commend the volume to all seeking an introduction to Abyssinian affairs and to the larger class of leaders who want a story of real living interest. As the object of the American mission was to overcome the effect of tariff barriers on the development of trade, there is also matter of moment in the book to Free Trader and Tariff Reformer alike. British political influence is strong in the country." The Abyssinian market is one well worth an effort to secure. We hope our mercahnts will take the hint.
*" Abyssiania of Today. By Ropert R. Skinner (London : Edward Arnold.)

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: There will be two appointments for Doctors in the Sudan Medical Department made about April next.
Candidates should foward all t estimonials to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum.
Information as to age, qualifications, engagments since qualifications, is required.
Candidates should be about 25 years old and unmarried, and should have a good knowledge of English and Arabic. Egyptians will be preferred.
Salary to commence at the rate of L.E. 20 er mensem, eligible for increase after two years' satisfactory service.
Applicants should be prepared to appear for interview about the 2nd week in March 1907, in Cairo.
Appointment for probation 3 months, afterwards for a year before being permanently admitted inot the Government service.
Sudan Agency, War Office, Cairo.
ALexandria, January 17,1907.

div.head: General Post Office.
div.p: An examination will be held at the Alexandria Post Office at 9 a.m. on the 11th February next, and at the Cairo Post Office at 9 a.m. on the 14th February next, for the purpose of filling vacanies of clerk on L.E. 5 per month and of apprentice on L.E. 3, according to the aviliability of the candidiate.

Intending candidates must be of Egyptian nationality and 18 years old, and must foward their applications to his Excellency the Postmater General, General Post Office, Alexandria, made out in their own handwriting on Ministerial Form No. 167 C.G. not later than the 9th February for ALexandria and the 12th for Cairo.
The following must accompany this Form:
1st Primary Education Certificate obtained within th elast three years
2nd A Certificate showing that the Candidate has paid his military exemption fee or that he has not yet been selected for conscription
If the candidate is attached to another Government Administration, he must obtain written permission to attend the examination from his chief and foward it together with the other documents.
Alexandira, January 29, 1907.

div.head: HELIOPOLIS OASIS
div.p: Nous avons promis d'exposer daus an deuxième artic'e l'état d'av moement des tra- vaux poursuivis au désert de l'Abbassieh, psr "The Cairo Bleotrio Railways and Heliopolis Oases Company."— C'est oe que nous uoui proposons de faire brièvement aojourd' hui.

Et d'abord rétablissement des routes.— Ce travail a été mené aveo une aotivité vraimeut merveilleuse par la Société de Travaux Pobltos do Caire et Mr. U. B. Knrr— En huit mois, o es entrepreneurs out cont'ait de m magnifiques roules sur une étendue de dix milles —Elles comprennent notamment one belle avenue d'une largeur de 40 mètres qui traverse la lère. Oasis dans tonte sa' profondeur, et des voies de vingt mètres, qni seront pourvues de larges trottoirs.— Tontes les routes présentement construites sont macadamisées à l'aide de la pierre ealoaire très dote qni fat en partie ex traite dn sol même des Oasis.— Les ar ères . importantes seront elles mêmes sillonnées par nue ligue de tramway éleotrique dont la Su j oiété a obtenu la oonoessioo et qni non seule ia uit patoonrra les deux oasis et les relirra i'une à l'antre, mais enoore viendra aboutir è l'Abbassieb. point termiuns de la ligne ox ploitée par la Soo'é'é des Tramways du Caire.
Les travaux de p'acement de la ligne de tramway des Oasis à l'Abbvssieh out été poue sés aveo aotivité.— La voie est posée sur une grande étendue. — Ou est oooupé è tendre le fil aérien.

Les Oasis, on le sait, seront admirablement reliées an Caire.: le ohemin de fer électrique dont laSooiété a la concession fera le parcours, sur siège spécial en 10 minutes de la premiè'e Oasis au Pont-Limoun et de là les voy ignora seront transportés, sans tricsbordemeit, par voie de tramways, sa oeatre même de la ctpi taie d'Egypte.

La Compagnie a fait procéder a Mwiitrau tion d'un vaste hôtel.— Ls monnmen', car o'en est on, édifié sur les plans de M. l'aroh - teote Jaspar, est entrepris par M M. Padova, Rotin & Co. Il affaote la forme semi-oirc ilaira et ne mtanre pas moins de 185 mètres de façvde — Co-Ç i dans le style arabe, ses ligues sont d'ans rare é égance 01 ne pent vraime it que féliciter l'babile architecte, dont les mé.itss ont déjà été officiellement o msaoréa au Caire dans des oonoonrs où il s'eit grandeur »nt distingné, d'avoir su mainteuir au b&'ime»t tonte sa distiuotiun et sou oarao'ère, eu dép>: de ses vastes proportions. L'Hô'-el qni atteint aujourd'hui su troisième étage en oompren Ira un quatrième. Il contiendra cinq omit oham bres, aveo oabinets de toilette et W.C. pour chaque paire de chambre* ; deux restaurant*, l'unau rrz-ie-ohans*ée, l'autre au 1er étage; des salles de réunion, salons, fomoits, salon» dt Isotare, bref toot oe qui rend nos grands bd tels oonlortables et agréibles.
La construction des villas est aussi en bonus voie d'exécution.

Dix villas sont en construction et la Corn pagnie oompte en taire édifier 100, per les soins de la Société de Travaux Publics d,i Caire, dont Sir Reginald Oakes est ans-i le Directeur Qéi éral. Ls Compagnies lait é'ablir, pour oes villas, det plan* de typas d ffé eut*. Certaines villas seront à un étage seulement, d'autres seront pourvues do denx étage , mais oorç tes dans det proportions différentes
Tontes les viHes auront jardin, à fabule et derrière; la partie Sod-Ousst des villas sera protégée do soleil par des vérandah-.

Nol doute que ces villas n'obtiennent un très grand snocèt, aussi bien auprès de la pu pulation qui reste è demeure an Caire, qu'au près de oeox qui se bornent à venir passer an Caire les mois d'biver, si désagréables en E i- rope.

En rdot, les 0asis, à Taltitrfile iù elles sont placées, 50 et O mè'res au dessus du niveao de la mer, forment bien le site le plus aéré, le plus soc et le plus salubra qui paisse se trouver dans la région du Caire.
Comment douter de la vogue d'une psreil'e région lorsqu'à ces qualités naturelle vien- dront s'ajouter les avantages de la réduction dn prix des loyers et du grand confort de l'habitation.

La Compagnie fait construire aussi are grande brasserie-restaurant dont l'entieprise a été confiée à M.M. Garozze et Figli. Le bâti ment est sous toit ; il sera achevé dans trois mois. Noos aurons là nue exploitation corn parable à oe qui existe dans les plus grandes capitales d'Burope.

Tandis que s'achève la brasserie re taurant. M M Padova, Kolin & Cie. font sortir de terre on grand family hôtel qui, anssiôtaohe, sera ooonpé provisoirement psr Us agei's de la Compagnie qui y résideront.

Enfin, signaloui nue dss oo-Htruotions les plus iutéressvotes peité ra q s'il nous ait éé donné de visiter : asile du "Garden-City", , presque oomplèterqeut aohsvéa et qui e t des tiuéo à abriter des travailleurs, hommes, fe n | mes, eu faut» au nombre de 7D0. ce q li dr assez sou importance.
Le bâtiment comprend deux étages; le rez i de obanssés est prévu poor des boutiques de tout genre; les hibitations sont de dimensions différentes et sont munies de ."lavatories" publics.

Teleste, si l'on y comprehnd encore des mage sins, ateliers on garages, et la pose de la oana | liaatiou d'eau qui desservira les Oisis, l'é at d'avanoemeot des travaux aprèi huit mois se lament d'exercice.

Les moia qui vont aolvie verront, avec la I ooustrnotion des nouvelles villas, s'élifi r les bâtimente d'aministration,l'église du cul'e catholique ait oeo'rede le 1ère Oasis, la moi i qnésarab1, et toites les constructions parti oulières tor lai tjrrains déjk vendus ou qu le seroput eucore daui un avenir proobtin, sans onblier le "Parc des 8poita" où l'on établira cbamp de course, tennis, jeu de polo, de gelf, orioket, en un mo', toit oe qui re'èva de ;a rubrique "Sports".

Evidem ment ce qui pré è le n'eet qu'un relevé très succint, an reflet très pâ'e de li réalité. E le m'eux qua nous pu ssions faire, en termes de conclusion, c'est de conseiller à nos lecteurs que roiart'olei auront intérese, d'y aller voir eux mêmes. Is revie liront de là aveo ce'te double imp-etaion que nous avons éprou- vée. à saviir la grsnduar, la beau'é et la grande utilité le l'oeivre entreprises, la certi- tude non seuleman' q t'elle sera menée à bonne fin, mais encore quielel est appelés à un snorèr énorms, dépassant les plus optimistes eapé rances.

div.head: Circulaire H.De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mardi 29 Janvier.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a été élevé hier de 1/8 à 4 7/8 poor cent An Stook Exchange, le Consolrdé anglais est resté invarié à 87 et l'Unifiée ù 109 1/2. La National Bank a perdu 1/8 à 28 1/8. L'Agricole est demeurés inchangée à 9 6/8, de même que la Dsira ù 17 1/2 et la Delta Light à 11 1/2.
A Paris, le Crélit Foncier Bgyptieu »Vst maintenu à 777 et la Barque d'Athènes à 135.

Ici la séancs d'aojoord'hni a présenté plus on moins la même physionomie que oelle d'hier, o'est è dire d'un marobé de liquidation. Affaires restreintes et tendance lourds sur presque tonte la ligne de la cote. Il importe tootetnis de noter qu'une certaine fermeté s'est mansfes'ée vers la clôture, enr quelques titres tout au moins, tels que la Csssa di Soo' to, l'Agricole et les fondateurs Entreprises Immobdières et Travaux.

Dans le compartiment des Barques, la Na- tional, qni avait fléchi an début à 27 7/8,s'ect relevée à 27 15/16 28. L'Agricole sest consoli- dés à 9 11/16. La Cassa di Soouto a regai né 8 francs a 979 280. Le Comptoir Financier a faibli à 7 13/16 7/8. la Bar que d'Atbèotsà 184 et la Banque d'Abyssinie à 5 3/16 1/4.

Le Crédit Foncier est resté à 778 ; sa part de fondateur a fléohi à 940. La Dsira a molli à 17 9/16. La Béhéra est revenne è 40. La Nile Land a progressé è 18 1/2. L'Allotmrnt s'est inscrit à 3 1/2. L'Immobilière a é'.é ra- menée à 381.

Leu Entreprises Immohil ères et Travaux se sont rrfferraies à 17 1/4 1/i. Leur part, qui, eu I cjnts do séanoe, avait fléchi à 325, est re moulée en o'ôtnre à 330. L'Epargrne Immobilière s'est maintenue à 3 3/4 ot sa part è 307, après avoir atteint 315. L'Expre»» Nile est resté à 5 7/16 et sa part à 305.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Cairo out décliné à 289 290. Les utomnbilos ont encore fléchi à 5 .1/8 et leur part è 11. Le» Egyptian Mail ont é é ramenés à 4.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hoelieres, les Nugovich out progressé à 22 3/4. Lis Egypt an out rétrogradé à 12 7/16. Les Exoe'sior ont reon'é à 4 3/8.

Parmi les petites valeors, la Delta Land s'est - tassée à 4 5/16 3/8- lus Silt and Soda ont avancé à 21 sb. 3- lus Estâtes se sont tenus ù I 1 9/16 et les Markets à 30 ,b S. Rien de ; particulier è relever sur les autres titres.

L'assemblée générale oxtrnordinairo de la Société d'Eutreprises Immobilières et do Tra vaux, convequée pour le 2 Jauvisr courant et qui, faute du quorum statutaire, avait été renvoyée an 29 du même mois, a été tenue ete après midi, k 4 henres, an siège social, aveune de Boulac, au Caire. 15,871 actions y éaiscnt représentées.

L'assemblée a approuvé a l'unanimité les diverses propositions portées a l'ordre du jour, notamment celle tendant a donner au conseil d'administration les pouvoirs nécessaires pour étodior et préparer un prejet de fusion entre la Sucé é et la maisou H. de Vries A Boutigny.
Il demnnre entendu que ce projet serait éventuellement exposé et soumis a une nonvelle assemblée générale extraordinaire qui aurait à statuer a son égard.

Une assemblée générale extraordinaire des actionnaires de la National Hotels and Rosi dences Co. est, corivcques pour le 13 Fevres prochain, a 4 h. p. m., au National Hotel, au Caire, pour délibérer sur la proposition de fusion avec Anglo Egyptian Hotels Co. et donner, le cas échéant, an conseil d'adminis- tration tous pouvoirs pour assurer l'exécution de ce project.

Confirmément a la résolution prise par l'au semblée générale extraordinaire du 5 Janvier 1907, le conseil d'administration de la Upper Egypt Hotels Co. a décidé d'émettre 22,000 actions nouvelles de L.B. 4, pour portet le ca pital social de L E 220,000 a 308,000.

Le taux d'émission a été fixé a L E. 4 1/2, soit avec P E 50 de prime, qui sera portée a la réserve Il est réservé anx porteurs d'actions anciennes un droit de préférence a la sous- cription a raison de 2 actions nouvelles peur 5 anciennes.
Les souscriptions seront recies, accompagnees du vertement de L. E 1 par titre, a la National Bank, au Caire et a Alexandrie, les 4, 5, et 6 Février prochain.
Suivant des i formations d'Alexandrie, la nouvelle émission do la Cassa di Sconto, en vue de l'augmentation da capital de cet éta- blissement deo élit, aurait lieu dans le course du mois prochain.

On annonçe, d'autre part, que la nouvelle émission d'autions ordinaires de la Khedivial Mail Co se ferait tres prochainement au prix de £ 1. 7. 6 et que 7 notions nouvelles seraient attribuéat pour 10 anciennes.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
